Take the output of the command "seq 0 5" (which is 0 1 2 3 4 5), pipe it to awk, which will generate a random number, pipe that to head to take the first line, pipe that to xargs to replace {} with the output of the previous command, pipe that to shuf to randomly shuffle the output of "ls -lS", and finally pipe that to head to take the first {} lines.
cmd: seq 0 5 | awk 'BEGIN{srand();}{print rand()}' | head -n 1 | xargs -I {} shuf -e ls -lS | head -{}

Send a request to the website 'http://www.random.org/strings/' with the user agent "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/56.0.2924.87 Safari/537.36", accept header "application/json", and parameters "num=1, len=32, digits=on, upperalpha=on, loweralpha=on, unique=on, format=plain, rnd=new". Then, remove all characters except for alphanumeric characters and fold the result into 16 character strings. Finally, take the first string from the result.
cmd: curl -A "Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/56.0.2924.87 Safari/537.36" -H "Accept: application/json" 'http://www.random.org/strings/?num=1&len=32&digits=on&upperalpha=on&loweralpha=on&unique=on&format=plain&rnd=new' | tr -dc "[:alpha:][:digit:]" | fold -w 16 | head -n 1

Find all directories (type d) in the current directory (.), with a minimum depth of 1 (mindepth 1), execute the stat command on each of them (exec stat {} \;), and print the integer of the second and third fields of the output of stat divided by 10 (awk -F. '{print int(($2*1000+$3)/10)}') and sort them numerically (sort -n). Then, print an error if the previous field is greater than the current field (awk -F: '{ if(prev>$1) print "ERROR"; prev=$1 }').
cmd: find . -mindepth 1 -type d -exec stat {} \; | awk -F. '{print int(($2*1000+$3)/10)}' | sort -n | awk -F: '{ if(prev>$1) print "ERROR"; prev=$1 }'

Sort the output of the command "find . -type f" (which finds all files in the current directory and its subdirectories), converting all uppercase letters to lowercase and cutting the output at the third field, and count the number of occurrences of each unique result, sorting the output in descending order.
cmd: sort <(find . -type f  | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]' | cut -d -f 3) | uniq -i -c | sort -nr

Find all files (-type f) in the current directory (~) and its subdirectories, calculate the disk usage (-du) in bytes (-b) and include total (-c), sort the output (-sort) in reverse numerical order (-rn) and display the top 5 (-head -n 5) results.
cmd: find ~ -type f | xargs du -bc | sort -rn | head -n 5

Find all files with the extension ".txt" in the current directory and its subdirectories, then use awk to split the file path into its components and use them to construct a URL to download the file from GitHub, then execute the command with bash.
cmd: find . -name "*.txt" | awk 'BEGIN { FS = "."; OFS="/" } { print "wget https://github.com/", $2 "/" $3 "/" $4 }' | bash

xargs -a <(shuf -i 0-255 -n 1024) -n 30 -d '\n' sed -i 's/^\(.\)/ig; s/^\([0-9]\)$/0\1/g'

This command will take the output of the shuf command (which randomly shuffles numbers between 0 and 255) and pass it to xargs. Xargs will then take 30 of these numbers at a time and pass them to sed, which will insert an 'i' at the beginning of each number and add a 0 to any single-digit numbers.

Find the file with the most occurrences of the ".sh" extension, calculate its MD5 checksum, print the checksum, sort the checksums, count the number of occurrences of each checksum, sort the counts in descending order, and display the top result.

invocation: Send an HTTP request with the user agent "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36" to the URL "https://73.44.44.44/f3452fde-d5f5-11e8-89eb-1d81f9a30d2a" and search for the pattern "file" : "[a-zA-Z0-9_.]+". Then, extract the last part of the pattern and add a dot before it. Finally, use the extracted part to copy the file from the URL to the "/home/BackUp" directory using SCP.
cmd: curl -A "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/72.0.3626.119 Safari/537.36" https://73.44.44.44/f3452fde-d5f5-11e8-89eb-1d81f9a30d2a | grep -oEi "file\" : \"[a-zA-Z0-9_.]+" | grep -oEi "[a-zA-Z0-9_.]+$" | sed -e 's/\(.*\)/.\1/' | xargs -I {} scp $USER@73.44.44.44:{} /home/BackUp

Set the TIMEOUT variable to 1 and the SECONDS variable to 20. Then, execute a loop that will sleep for 0.1 seconds and break when the current time minus the SECONDS variable is less than 0. Finally, echo a random number between 0 and 9.
cmd: env TIMEOUT=1 SECONDS=20 sh -c ' while sleep 0.1; do [ $( expr $( date +%s ) - $SECONDS ) -lt 0 ] || break; done; echo $(($RANDOM % 10)) '

Set an environment variable with a random string of 64 characters, then run a bash command that sleeps for a random number between 0 and 4, and prints a random number between 0 and 128.
cmd: env $(cat /dev/urandom | tr -dc 'a-zA-Z0-9_!@#$%^&*()' | head -c64) bash -c "sleep $(cat /dev/urandom | tr -cd '0-4' | head -c1);echo \$(echo \$RANDOM\%128)"
